availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Midas: an English burletta. As it is performed, at the Theatre-Royal, in Covent-Garden.
titleStmt.author: O'Hara, Kane, 1714?-1782.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed, for G. Kearsly, W. Griffin, J. Coote, T. Lownds, and W. Nicoll,

notesStmt.note: With a half-title bearing the price.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it is performed, at the THEATRE-ROYAL, IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed, for G. KEARSLY, W. GRIFFIN, J. COOTE, T. LOWNDS, and W. NICOLE.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
THE Editor of the following piece thinks proper to obſerve, that the firſt idea of it was conceived, and the plan in ſome meaſure executed by a gentleman in Dublin, for the private entertainment of ſome perſons of diſtinction in that kingdom, at a time, when Italian Burlettas were blended with the exhibitions of the Theatre, and almoſt triumphed over the beſt productions in our language. The public ſpirit of thoſe, for whom it was originally intended, prevailed upon the author to enlarge his deſign. Accordingly, MIDAS adventured on the ſtage, and met with uncommon ſucceſs for a ſeries of nights. The Editor begs leave to add a word concerning the ſtile which prevails in the following ſcenes. They are written in the true ſpirit of the mock-heroic. BURLESQUE, in all times, from the ſtage of ATHENS down to the DRAGON OF WANTLEY, has been eſteemed one of the provinces of the Drama. It's
humour principally conſiſts in making dignified perſonages raiſe in our minds trite and ordinary ideas, or elſe in giving to trivial objects a ſerious air of gravity and importance.

It would be impertinent to point out inſtances in either way of compoſition; but thus much was deemed neceſſary that no one ſhould look for another ſort of entertainment than was here intended. The public, with their uſual candour, will conſider the particular ſcope of this piece, and will decide nothing till they have heard the muſick, to which it is adapted. Should MIDAS in the repreſentation be found to have merit, and indeed, excellence in its kind; the generous critick will allow the author that degree of applauſe, which his talents ſeem to deſerve.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.
div.p: SCENE, firſt on mount Olympus, afterwards on the paſtures of Lydia.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: The curtain riſing diſcovers the Heathen Deities, ſeated amidſt the clouds, in full council: they addreſs Jupiter in chorus, accompanied by all the inſtruments.
AIR I. King of Pruſſia's March. Chorus of all the Gods.

l.hi: Earth's globe is but his taw.

sp.speaker: Jup
sp.l: Immortals, you have heard your plaintive ſovereign
And Culprit Sol's high crimes. Shall we who govern
Brook ſpies upon us? Shall Apollo trample
On our commands? we'll make him an example.
As for you, Juno, curb your prying temper, or
We'll make you to your coſt, know,—we're your emperor,
Your huſband—when the jealous Gad-bee twitches,
Swallow your ſpittle—Jove will wear the breeches.
sp.stage: AIR II. To its own tune.

l.hi: 'Tis a curſe to be too knowing
Beſt let things take their chance.

sp.speaker: Juno
sp.l: What new rape is toward? To ſixes and ſevens,
This tyrant, for it's ſake, will jumble the heavens.
I'll take the law. (to Jup.) My proctor, with a ſummons
Shall cite you, ſir, t'appear at Doctor's Commons.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Let him—but firſt I'll chaſe from Heaven yon varlet,

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.l: What, for detecting you and your vile harlot?
Fine ſcheme! baniſh the Sun! drive out Apollo!
That you, of lawleſs love, deep draughts may ſwallow.
You'll then not need, thou grand monarque of Horners,
Skulk with your miſſes into holes and corners.

l.hi: Thus to wrong my chaſte love,
For ſpite of your rakehelly godhead
Nor be, of dues nuptial, defrauded.
In vain you in darkneſs encloſe them,

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Peace termagant, I ſwear by Styx—our thunder
Shall hurl him to the earth.

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: Sire, we knock under.
Ha, ha, ha, (Aſide) O jeſt moſt precious!
'Twill ſerve a thouſand years hence to refreſh us.
I ſay, down with him, Jove—exert your puiſſance,
Morbleu, the puppy's grown a public nuiſance,
Ay, ay, ſhort work—put out the light, and then—
sp.stage: AIR V. There was a jovial Beggar.

l.hi: For lewd, or chaſte, or foul, or fair,

lg.l: When a ſporting all may go, may go, may go, &c.

l.hi: Screen'd from the huſband's jealous eyes,
All love, all free as air,
No wanton need to fear ſurprize
Oh what a life were there!
Then hey for trumps, for matadores
Old maids will fly, when paſt amours,

sp.speaker: Jove.
sp.l: O brave, we nod his doom!

sp.speaker: Apollo.
sp.l: Hold, hold, have patience
Papa—No bowels far your own relations!

lg.l: What can this hurly-burly, this helter-ſkelter mean?
Jove looks confounded ſurly!—Chaos is come again.

sp.stage: AIR VI. To It's own tune.

l.hi: Maugre your bolts, and wiſe head,
The world will think you mad.
What worſe can Bacchus teach men,
Then break the lamps, beat watchmen

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You ſaucy ſcoundrel—there ſir—come Diſorder,
Down Phoebus, down to earth, we'll hear no farther.

lg.l: Roll, thunders, roll, blue lightnings flaſh around him,
The blab ſhall find our ſky can do without him.

div.stage: Thunder and lightning. Jupiter darts a bolt at him, he falls.—Jupiter re-aſſumes his throne, and the Gods all aſcend together, ſinging the initial chorus. Jove in his chair, &c.

SCENE A Champaign country with a diſtant village; violent ſtorm of thunder and lightning. Shepherds ſleeping in the field are rouzed by it and run away frighted. One leaves his cloak, hat, and guittar behind him. Apollo is ſeen whirling in the air, as caſt from heav'n; he falls to earth, with a rude ſhock, and lies for a while, ſtunn'd: at length he begins to move, riſes, advances, and looking upward, ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: Zooks! what a cruſh! a pretty decent tumble!
Kind uſage, Mr. Jove—ſweet ſir—your humble.
Well, down, I am;—no bones broke—tho' ſorely pepper'd!
Here doom'd to ſtay.—What can I do?—turn ſhepherd.
A lucky thought.—In this diſguiſe, Apollo
No more but Pol, the ſwain, ſome flock I'll follow.
Nor doubt I, with my voice, guittar, and perſon,
Among the nymphs to kick up ſome diverſion.
sp.stage: AIR VII. Hang me if I marry.

l.hi: With fun, my diſgrace I'll parry
While here on earth, I tarry,
With the nymphs, in my way,
But hang me if I marry—hang me if I marry
Let the ſky go to wreck, and miſcarry,
To toy, but never marry—toy, but never marry.

sp.speaker: Sileno.
sp.l: Whom have we here! a ſightly clown!—and ſturdy!
Hum—plays, I ſee, upon the hurdy-gurdy.
Seems out of place—a ſtranger,—all in tatters,
I'll hire him—he'll divert my wife and daughters.
—Whence, and what art thou boy?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: An orphan lad, Sir;
Pol is my name;—a ſhepherd once my dad, Sir;
I'th upper parts here—tho' not born to ſerving.
I'll now take on, for, faith, I'm almoſt ſtarving.

sp.speaker: Selino.
sp.l: You've drawn a prize i'th' lottery.—So have I too;
Why,— I'm the maſter you could beſt apply to.
sp.stage: AIR VIII. To it's own tune.

l.hi: Since you mean to hire for ſervice
Come with me, you jolly dog,
You can help to bring home harveſt,
Tend the ſheep, and feed the hog.
With three crowns, your ſtanding wages,
Bacon, beans, ſalt beef and cabbage,
Come ſtrike hands, you'll live in clover,
When we get you once at home,
We'll all dance to your ſtrum, ſtrum.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: From Nectar, and Ambroſia, 'tis coarſe diet;
When I was well, why could I not be quiet.
sp.stage: (After a pauſe takes Sileno by the hand and ſings to the foregoing air.)

l.hi: Done, ſtrike hands, I take your offer,
Farther on, I may fare worſe,
Zooks, I can no longer ſuffer,
Do, ſtrike hands; 'tis kind I offer,
I ſtrike hands, and take your offer,
Farther on I may fare worſe,
Pity ſuch a lad, ſhould ſuffer,
Zooks, I can no longer ſuffer,

div.stage: Exeunt, dancing, and ſinging the chorus.
Daphne and Nyſa, diſcover'd running,—their ſpinning-wheels over turned.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: But Nyſa, how goes on ſquire Midas' courtſhip?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Your ſweet Damaetas, pimp to his great worſhip
Brought me from him a purſe;—but the conditions—
—I've cur'd him, I believe, of ſuch commiſſions.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: The moon-calf! this muſt blaſt him with my father.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.p: Right. So we'er rid of the two frights together.
sp.stage: AIR IX. If 'tis joy to wound a Lover.

l.hi: If the ſwain we ſigh for preſs us,
If the fright we loath addreſs us

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Arch Monkey, hang me if I thought 'twas in you.
Well Ny—work you your Squire—as for my Ninny—
If he ſhan't curſe—then call me driv'ling Gipſey—
The hour that firſt on Daph he caſt a ſheep's eye.

l.hi: If I cannot plague the lubber,
Now I have him in my crib,
If, when he begins to blubber,
I can't ſoothe or laugh, or fib,
Doom'd for life, I may be,
And to wear a ſlabb'ring bib.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha!—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Hey-day! what mare's neſt's found?—For ever grinning:
Ye rantipoles—is't thus you mind your ſpinning.

l.hi: And this and that way ſidle.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now, dame, and girls, no more let's hear you grumble
At too hard toil:—I chanc'd, juſt now, to ſtumble,
On this ſtout drudge,—and hir'd him—fit for labour.
To'm lad—then he can play and ſing and caper.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: He ſhall not ſtay—unknown to me to hire him,
A lath!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nay there you're out,—no toil can tire him.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Gad's me! your diſtance, ſcare-crow! curſed civil!
Beggars once mounted, gallop to the devil.
Gaffer, (to Sil.) your blunders every hour ſurprize one:
This waſhy clout a drudge!—ah, thou'rt a wiſe one.
Fine rubbiſh to bring home, a ſtrolling thrummer!
(to Pol.) What art thou good for? ſpeak, thou ragged mummer.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Peace, ſaucebox, or I'll maul you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Goody, my ſtrength and parts you under value.
For his and your work, I am briſk and handy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Our Gammer, ſure, has tipt her 〈◊〉 of ſtingo!
Am I Apollo, and muſt bear this lingo?
sp.stage: AIR XII. A tune in Queen Mab.

l.hi: Pray goody, pleaſe to moderate the rancour of your tongue:
Why flaſh thoſe ſparks of fury from your eyes?
Remember, when the judgement's weak, the prejudice is strong.
A ſtranger why will you deſpiſe?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Sirrah, this inſolence deſerves a drubbing.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: With what ſweet temper he bears all her ſnubbing (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Oons, no more words—go boy, and get your dinner.
Fye, why ſo croſs grain'd to a young beginner?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: So modeſt!

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: So genteel!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Not pert, nor lumpiſh.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Would he were hang'd!

sp.speaker: Nyſ. and Daph.
sp.l: La! mother, why ſo frumpiſh?

div.stage: AIR XIII. To the tune of, Non, Non, volette n'eſt paint trompeuſe.

l.hi: Mama, how can you be ſo ill-natured,
To a lad, ſo limb'd, ſo feature'd,
Girls, for you my fears perplex me
Wife, in vain you tieze and vex me,
Mama, how can you be ſo illnatur'd,
Ah, ah, to a lad ſo limb'd, ſo featured?
Girls, for you my fears perplex me,
Wife in vain you tieze and vex me
Mama, how can yon be ſo ill-natured,
Pſha, pſha, you muſt not be ſo ill-natur'd;
Ah, ah, to a lad ſo limb'd, ſo featur'd,
T'is my pleaſure to give pain.

div.stage: Squire Midas diſcovered in his parlour, ſmoaking his pipe, lolling in an eaſy chair. Damaetas waiting at a reſpectful diſtance.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Nyſa, you ſay, refuſ'd the guineas Britiſh.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ah! pleaſe your worſhip—ſhe is wond'rous ſkittiſh.
Out, pimp, ſaid ſhe,—take back to him who ſent it, That traſh—

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Death!—ſcorn'd!—the minx ſhall ſore repent it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: She ſcorns you—

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: But when you told her what I meant to ſettle—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: She flounc'd, you'd ſwear her tongue was of bell-metal.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: I'll have her, coſt what 'twill, odſbods—I'll force her—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: The halter—

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: As for madam, I'll divorce her.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: The biſhop's court—lard help your paper noddle!
Did ſhe not give the ſlip to young Sir Dawdle?
Her ſitter Daphne too, a curſe upon her,
Uſes me worſe, than Niſa does your honour.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Some favour'd lout incog our bliſs oppoſes,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ay, Pol, the hind, puts out of joint our noſes.
sp.stage: AIR XIV. Fanny's fairer than a flower.

l.hi: Wretched he, whoſe pain or pleaſure
Such the merchant's ſtate, whoſe treaſure
Swims the ſport of tide and wind.
Shifts her lover, like her ſmock.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: I've heard of that Pol's tricks,—of his ſly tampering
To fling poor Pan, but I'll ſoon ſend him ſcampering.
An upſtart!—rival me!—by George, I'll pheaze him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Sir, he bewitches every girl that ſees him.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: 'Sblood, I'll commit him—drive him to the gallows!
Where is old Pan?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Tipling, Sir, at th' ale-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Run, fetch him—we ſhall hit on ſome expedient—
To rout this Pol.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: I fly, (going returns) Sir, your obedient.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: What boots my being Squire
Juſtice of Peace, and Quorum?
Church-warden—knight o'th' ſhire,
And Cuſtos Rotulorum?
If ſaucy little Nyſa's heart rebellious,
My ſquireſhip ſlights, and hanckers after fellows?
sp.stage: AIR XV. To a French tune, A la Santé du Pere d'Oleron.

l.hi: Shall a paltry clown, not fit to wipe my ſhoes

lg.l: Shall a peaſant minx, when juſtice Midas wooes

l.hi: Her noſe up at him toſs?

lg.l: I'll ſell her Pol a ſlave, get mundungus in exchange,

l.hi: So glut to the height of pleaſure,

div.stage: Pan is diſcovered ſitting at a table, with a tankard, pipes, and tobacco before him, his bagpipes lying by him.

l.hi: He rules the roast in the ſky,
Yet he's a fool if he thinks
That he's as happy as I.
And leads his highneſs a weary life;
And ſtrole a batchelor's merry life.
Yet cringe to his harridan's furbella;
And clink the cannikin here below.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: There ſits the old ſoaker—his pate troubling little
How the world wags—ſo he gets drink and vittle:
Hoa, maſter Pan!—Gad you've trod on a thiſtle!
You may pack up your all, ſir, and go whiſtle.
The wenches have turn'd tail—to yon buck-ranter,
Tickled by his guittar—they ſcorn your chanter.
sp.stage: AIR XVII. Tune in Pant. of Fortunatus

l.hi: All around the maypole how they trot,
There is old Sileno friſks like a mad

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O blood, and guts! What, dare the tinkler ſcurvy
Intrude, to turn my wenches topſy turvy?
A fop! chouſe me out of my choice trol-lops,
I'll ſmaſh his trim guittar—about his chaps.
sp.stage: AIR XVIII. My wife's a galloping, &c.

l.hi: Shall he run away with the laſſes
By his trills, and his ſlurs, and his graces,
From me who at fairs, and horſe-races,
Have pip'd to the laird of the clan.
A fribble!—If I can but catch him
I'll pummel—I'll pinch, and I'll ſcratch him,
I warrant I'll make him not match him
Self as a muſician with Pan.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Keep yourſelf cool, good maſter Pan—this courage
Is thrown away—Pol's a mere chip in Porridge;
Softly and fair—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You're right;—our Squire, when mellow,
'Tis he ſhall do't—he's a rough, hect'ring fellow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why he ſent me for you—He, with kicks o'th' crupper,
Will make Pol dance—He'll gi'n ſalt eel to's ſupper.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Step you before—I'll but juſt pay my reck'ning
And in a crack attend his worſhip's beck'ning.

div.stage: He throws ſome pieces on the table, and departing is met by

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: O Pan! the devil to pay—both my ſluts frantic!
Both in their tantrums, for yon cap'ring antick.
Rivals forſooth!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What, for a ſtraggling goatherd!

sp.speaker: Myſ
sp.l: For this fine piece of work—thanks to my dotard.

l.hi: Sure I ſhall run with vexation diſtracted,
To ſee my purpoſes thus counter-acted!
This way, or that way, or which way ſoever,
All things run contrary to my endeavour.
Nurſing in boſom a treacherous viper;
Here's a fine dance—but 'tis he pays the piper:.

lg.l: But I'll go ſeek 'em all—and if I find 'em,
I'll drive 'em—as if Old Nick were behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Soa, ſoa,—don't flounce;
Avaſt—diſguiſe your fury.
Pol we ſhall trounce.
Midas is judge and jury.

l.hi: 'Till be ceaſe of your love to be doubtful.
Look one, but row another way.
Says no, to the mitre that would fill his wiſh up▪
And ſwallows him up at a mouthful.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Out on't, I'll act above-board—I'll ne'er flatter,
Not I—I ſcorn it—tell me no ſuch matter.
My goſſips all would loll their tongues,
To ſee me with my vengeance trifle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ay, but to pay him home thoſe wrongs,
Your tranſports you muſt ſtifle.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Srifle!—dye firſt! ſhall Myſis ſtoop to crawling!
No—by my will—theſe hands ſhould ſtretch him ſprawling.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You do but put him on his guard by bawling
sp.stage: AIR. XXI. Duett. Gavott in Overt. Otho.

div.stage: Dance of Satyrs, Fauns, and Dryads.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: An old grove, in the midſt, the old oracular oak by it ſelf, its boughs decorated with votive wreaths. Enter Sileno alone, a garland in his hand. He ſeems ſtruck with religious horror at the gloomy ſolitude. During the ſymphony he advances timorouſly, and hangs his garland on a branch:

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Hail, myſtic oak!—zooks what a taking
Am I now in!—oh, how I ſhiver!
I'm in an ague—ha! the very ſhaking
Of the leaves, throws me all over int'a quaking,—
My wife! I'll ne'er forgive her—
I'm wet as in a river—
Ah! ha! there—what was't gave me a twitch?
It muſt have been a witch,
Or ſomething diabolic.
Oh, 'tis a fooliſh frolic.

div.stage: (Thunder and lightning—Sileno retires trembling to a corner of the ſtage, and there falls on his knees with hands uplifted.)
Duett. AIR I. To its own tune.

l.hi: Yet known never to be wrong.
Yet known never to be wrong.

sp.speaker: Sil.

l.hi: Is my dame mov'd by the devil

sp.l: That ſhe can't to Pol be civil?

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.l: To Pol be civil.

l.hi: Say, what means the ſhrewiſh fripp'ry
Dinn'ng ſtill that girls are ſlipp'ry?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Dupes ſhall we all by Pol be made.

sp.speaker: Ora.
sp.l: All by Pol be made.

l.hi: If I don't diſcard the lad.
Oh fye, wooden Oracle, fye for ſhame
To let me go back as wife as I came.

div.stage: SCENE. A Wood. A wood, and lawn near Sileno's farm, flocks grazing at a diſtance,—a tender ſlow ſymphony. Enter Daphne, walks about melancholic and ſilent; at length lays herſelf down on a bank abſorbed in meditation. Nyſa watching her.

sp.speaker: Nyſa.
sp.l: O ho'! is it ſo—Miſs Daphne in the dumps,
Mum—ſnugs the word—I'll lead her ſuch a dance
Shall make her ſtir her ſtumps.
To all her ſecret haunts,
Like her ſhadow, I'll follow and watch her:
And, faith, mamma ſhall hear on't if I catch her.
sp.stage: AIR III. From tree to tree.

l.hi: And ſcarcely can our own ſucceſs,
A kind of victory we feel,
Deny'd a real bliſs, we steal

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: La! how my heart goes pit-a-pat what thumping
E'er ſince my father brought us home this bumpkin.
Heigho!—heigho!—yet why
Mope thus and ſigh?
Has not the fellow eyes as well as I?
Gad's heart o' grace I'll pluck up;
Throw myſelf in his way and pump him,
Appear leſs ſtarch'd and ſtuck up.
Then let him gueſs my meaning by my mumping.
sp.stage: AIR IV. To a French tune, Quand on Scait aimer et plair.

l.hi: He's as tight a lad to ſee to,
As e'er ſtept in leather ſhoe
And, what's better, he'll love me too,
And to him I'll prove true blue.
Tho' my ſiſter caſts a Hawk's eye
I defy what ſhe can do.
He o'er looked the little Doxy,
I'm the girl he means to woo.
Hither I ſtole out to meet him,
He'll, no doubt, my ſteps purſue,
If the youth prove true, I'll fit him;
If he's falſe,—I'll fit him too.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Think o' the devil—'tis ſaid,
He's at your ſhoulder—
This wench was running in my head,
And pop—behold her.
Such fair occaſions are not met with often,
What if I touch the tender vein,
And whine ſome melting, plaintive ſtrain
Her heart to ſoften.
sp.stage: AIR V. When on the dear boſom lying.

l.hi: At your feet a tender ſwain
Prays you will not let him languiſh,
One kind look would eaſe his pain.
Did you know the lad who courts you
He not long needs ſue in vain;
Prince of ſong, of dance of ſports—you
Scarce will meet his like again.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Sir; you're ſuch an oglio,
Of perfection in folio,
No damſel can reſiſt you:
Your face ſo attractive,
Limbs ſo ſupple and active,
That by this light,
At the firſt ſight,
I could have run and kiſs'd you.
sp.stage: AIR VI. The prieſt in his boots.

l.hi: If you can caper, as well as you modulate,
With the addition of that pretty face,

lg.l: Pan, who was held by our ſhepherds a God o' late;

l.hi: Will be kick'd out, and you ſet in his place.
His beard ſo frowſy, his geſtures ſo awkward are
And his bag-pipe has ſo drowſy a drone,
That if they find you, as I did, no backwarder,
You may count an all the girls as your own.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I aſk but you—and yours I'll be for ever.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: How can I truſt?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You may, you muſt.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Vows are brittle,
You'll prove fickle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I'll die firſt.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: That's clever.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: D' you think I'll range:
Againſt all change,
Your charms are my heart's armour.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Pol, Pol, make haſte, come hither.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Death, what a time to call,
Oh! not your old lungs of leather.
B'ye Daph.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: B'ye Pol.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My charmer.
sp.stage: AIR VII. An Italian tune of Peſcetti.

div.stage: (During the ſymphony, they take a tender leave and part) Exit. Pol.
Nyſa burſts from her lurking place.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Marry come up, forſooth,
I'ſt me, you forward vixen,
You chooſe to play your tricks on?
And could your liquoriſh tooth
Find none but my ſweetheart to fix on?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Marry come up a gain.
Indeed! my dirty couſin!
Have you a right to every ſwain?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Ay, tho' a dozen.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: My minikin miſs,—do you fancy that Pol

l.hi: Can ever be caught by an infant's dol?
Can you, miſs Maypole, ſuppoſe he will fall
In love with the gyanteſs of Guild-hall?
You will lie 'till your mouldy upon the ſhelf.
You ſtump o'th' gutter, you hop o' my thumb,
A huſband for you muſt from Lilliput come,
You ſtalking ſteeple, you gawky stag,
Your huſband muſt come from Brobdignag.
I'll humble your vanity miſtreſs Trapes.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: No more of thoſe freedoms miſs Nyſa, I beg,

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Miſs Daphne's, conceit muſt be lower'd a peg.

l.hi: Do, ſhew your teeth, ſpitfire, do, but you can't bite.
This haughtineſs ſoon will he laid in the dirt,

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Good lack! what is come o'er me?
I'm all bewitched, untwiſted.
Ah! Cupid, thou'rt a wizard
Thy ſpells are not to be reſiſted.
Alas, Daphne, has ſtep'd before me!
Envy and love, devour me.
Pol, doats upon her phiz hard
'Tis that, 'tis that ſticks in my gizzard.
Midas appears now twenty times more hideous
Ah, Nyſa, what reſource?—a cloyſter.
Death alive—yet thither muſt I run,
And turn nun.
Leſt hurried by love prodigious
Or lur'd by hope inſidious,
I be by Pol undone,
As you'd undo an oyſter.
sp.stage: AIR IX. A French. tune, Aſſis ſur l'Herbertte.

div.stage: Going out, is met by MIDAS, entering.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Turn, tygreſs, turn; nay fly not—
I have thee at a why not.
How comes it, little Nyſa,
That heart to me ſo icy
Should be to Pol like tinder
Burnt up t'a very cinder?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Sir, to my virtue ever ſteady,
Firm as a rock
I ſcorn your ſhock,
But why this attack?
A miſtreſs can you lack
Who have a wife already?

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Ay there's the curſe—but ſhe is old and ſickly;
And would my Nyſa grant the favour quickly,
Would ſhe yield now—I ſwear by the Old Harry
The moment madam's coffin'd—Her I'll marry.

l.hi: When my wife is laid in ground
When my wife's laid in the ground.
Oh how happy ſhould I be
Would little Nyſa pig with me.
Would little Nyſa pig with me.

sp.speaker: Nyſa.
sp.l: Young birds alone are caught with chaff,
But think not, ſquire, this farce on
Me e're ſhall paſs;
At your baſe ſcheme I laugh,
E'er I fall to, the grace
Shall be pronounced by the parſon.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Yet take my vows.—

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: I would not take your bond, ſir,—

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Half my eſtate—

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: No, nor the whole,—my fond ſir.

l.hi: Ne'er will I be left i'th' lurch,
'Till I'm made a bride i'th' church
Can your palace, plate or coach,
Bridle the tongue of foul reproach?

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Well, maſter Pol I'll tickle,
For him, at leaſt, I have a rod in pickle:
When he's in limbo
Not thus our hoity toity miſs
Will ſtick her arms a kimbo.

l.hi: Steals ſlily, your poultry to ravage, to ravage.
All's fair to deſtroy the fell ſavage, fell ſavage.
No means do I ſcruple to baniſh, to baniſh.
By hook, or by crook he ſhall vaniſh, ſhall vaniſh.

div.stage: Going out, he is met by PAN.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So ſquire, well met.—I flew to know your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Why, Pan, this Pol we muſt bring down on his knees.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: That were a feat indeed!—a feat to brag on.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Let's home—we'll there concert it o'er 〈◊〉 flagon.
I'll make him ſkip—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: As St. George did the dragon.

l.hi: Let his ſhoulder feel your laſh on't.
Of your dear Nyſa beguile ye—
Will but diſgrace and defile ye •
Are the meaſures fitteſt for ye.
Thus we gain the point we drive at

div.stage: SCENE a Room in SILENO'S Houſe. Daphne diſcovered at work.
Enter DAMAETAS, who ſees her not.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Heigho! my very heart will burſt aſunder,
What ſtar malign was I born under!
A muckworm herd
To me preferr'd,
O blood and thunder!
Ha, Daph, alone!—To ſilence
I'm aw'd—The Devil's in it.
Have at her—Here goes—.
Should ſhe conſent—who knows,
This may be the critical minute;
For ever loſt a while hence!
Egad, I'm all agog on't.
Seize Time by the forelock,
E'en make a hog, or a dog on't;
The bolder puſh, the more luck.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Who ſent for you, you hoddy doddy?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: There, now, how croſs!— (to her)
Nobody.
I came o'myſelf, as uſual,
The queſtion to pop.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Get you gone, you milk-ſop;
What, after my refuſal!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ah Daphne, you ſtop the breath o' me;
Huſſey, you'll be the death o' me.
Ah, why, dear girl, why take up with that beggar,
And uſe your own Damaetas like a neger?
sp.stage: AIR XIV. Tune, Nanny of the Hill,

l.hi: Since firſt thoſe eyes enſlav'd my heart
My looks betray my inward ſmart,
Ah cruel! ah cruel! ah cruel, cruel Daph.
Inhuman maid, my ſighs you ſcout,
My tears but make you laugh,
Yet at firſt ſight, an upſtart lout
Ah fickle! ah fickle! ah fickle, fickle Daph.
How can you on my courtſhip frown,
Yet ſuffer ſuch a clumſy clown
To win and tickle, to win and tickle Daph.

sp.speaker: Daph.

lg.l: Who gave you leave my actions
Farther a field I weet you
For fear this beggar meet you

sp.stage: AIR XV. A French tune. Tourteulle.

l.hi: Yes; your wealth I hold at nought,
Daphne's heart ſhall ne'er be bought;
Would lock her up like his guinea.
In your pain my pleaſure is,
Jealous dolt, I hate your phiz,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Hey toſs! Sh'as paid me ſoundly!
A ſwinging rap o'th' knuckles.
Well, to theſe honeyſuckles
He's a meer oaf who truckles.
For miſs the more he buckles
To, and will on ground lye,
The more curvetts and chuckles.
sp.stage: AIR XVI. Farewel the Hills and Vallies.

l.hi: His foe it is to puſh!
He's mad on death to ruſh.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why—is the devil in you Gammer.
Have I no refuge from your clamour?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Was ever wife ſo baſely treated?
So croſs'd, ſo gaul'd, ſo fretted!
O Gods! I ſhall run crazy
Mad, mad!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: No March-hare madder,
Do, lambkin give it vent,—'twill eaſe you;
And make your heart the gladder.
sp.stage: AIR XVII. When that I was a little tiny Boy.

l.hi: When gathering clouds obſcure the ſky
The thunders rowl, and the lightnings fly;
So when a vixen's paſſions ſwell
Boſom rent by fiends of hell,
At length tears ſtream—and all is well.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Well!—I'll be even with that ſpark yet.
Of fiſh a dainty kettle
You have dreſt—you numſcul beetle;
You've brought your hogs to a fair market.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why!—I'm all i'th' dark yet.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Know then thou peerleſs blockhead,
Your ſcoundrel, would he were choaked,
With his quips, and his quillets
And running his rigs
With both your daughters has intrigues
Nay here, read but theſe billets—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Pſha! put them in your pocket
Did not the ſacred oak,

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: I mock it—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Swear to me, on his conſcience
That by Pol's means—

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: His means!—what nonſenſe!—
But I've a plot ſhall make you rue,
And keep the houſe too hot for you;
Don't be ſurpriz'd, if on the ſudden,
Your minion give the crow a pudding
Soon mounted in the air, if
You chance to ſee the cudden
A caper cut before the ſheriff.
sp.stage: AIR XVIII. To an Italian Opera tune.

l.hi: The wolf that ſlaughter'd finds her whelps,
Their murtherer tracks with ſhrilleſt yelps,

lg.l: So my revenge ſhall Pol purſue,

l.hi: 'Tll at the gallows tree he rue
The wrongs he did my daughters.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Gad's bud, I dread her vengeance
An angry woman to deſtroy
What ſhe hates, would employ
The devil, and all his emgines.
Pol, here's a ſtorm a brewing.
Old Pan, and our Myſis
Are hatching devices
To perpetrate your ruin.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Alas, what have I done—poor ſtranger!
Won't you protect me, ſir, from danger?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Tut, they ſhall find I ken 'em,
And on themſelves can turn their venom,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Poor fools! how weak, how ſhallow
Are all your plots againſt Apollo.
Theſe clowns I pity—but my ſpleen 'twill pamper
Midas and Pan to hamper,
Their projects to quaſh
And their pride to abaſh,
When all my rays burſt on them with one flaſh.
How I ſhall laugh, when huddled in a clu • ter,
They ſtare, gaping like ſtuck pigs at my luſtre.
sp.stage: AIR XIX. When Faries dance round on the graſs.

l.hi: When fairies dance round on the graſs
And revel to night's awful noon,
Each elf with his tight little laſs
Trips to the pale light of the moon,
If't chance that the grey dawn of day
Peep in on their frolicks too ſoon,
In fright they all ſcuttle away,
And follow the glimpſe of the moon.

div.stage: (As he is going off, enter Daphne on one ſide, Nyſa on the other, both run to him.)

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: O Pol! the fat's all in the fire!

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Such banging
In ſtore for us.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: For you no leſs than hanging.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The devil there is!—what means this ſad haranguing?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Fly, falſe deluder.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Quick, take leg, deceitful—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Take leg, and quit my girls! that were ungrateful.
sp.stage: AIR XX. To it's own tune.

l.hi: That it cannot find room for fear,
Such a love is not worth my care
For your vows are falſe as air.
What heart without ſhedding a tear,
I'd eſcort you with pleaſure my dear,
What gallows ſo bad as deſpair.
Your falſhood ſhall ne'er again grieve me.
Take my word, and my oath,
That at night I will ſatisfy both.
That at night I will ſatisfy both.
How, will you at night ſatisfy both?
No, you never can ſatisfy both.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: During the ſymphony, Mercury deſcends, and walks to and fro, tolling a bell, at intervals, as a public cryer; at the cloſe, in broken air, he publiſhes the following advertiſements.

sp.speaker: Merc.

l.hi: O yes, O yes, O yes, this is to give notice.
Or reel'd down to earth, when maudlin,
As a ſwitch tall and thin
Ne'er a rag to his ſkin,

sp.l: And anſwers to the name of Apollo.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Huſh ribald cur, this bawling
Unleſs you wiſh a mawling!
Heaven's, what a ſink of ſlander your foul throat is!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh are you there, maſter Apollo?
My elbow itch'd; I gueſs'd at what would follow.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are a rogue beneath my notice.
sp.stage: AIR II. Kiſs me faſt my mother's coming.

l.hi: Worth diſgrac'd dares hack and whittle
See the game cock's creſt with mud upon't;
Strait the dunghill breed grows proud upon't,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Come come, let's buſs, and friends.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Not 'till I curry your mungril hide.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Poo, let's ſhake hands, my hurry
Barr'd compliments.—Pray, pray, 'twas joke—I'm ſorry.
Jove's in a raging fume, a pelting chafe!
Oh! 'tis ſuch fun, would make even Pluto laugh!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Do, let me know't.—I long, for his late kindneſs
To have him on the hip.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Hark then.—His highneſs,
Safe as he thought himſelf from your inquires,
Sruck up an aſſignation with Miſs Iris:
Juno o'er heard it all—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: —So had them track'd,
I do ſuppoſe, and caught them in the fact.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Ah, madam's an old hand:—ſhe better judging,
Lock'd Iris up, and ſlipt into her lodging;
Lay ſnug—far'd well—ne'er cried, roaſt meat, but chuckled,
While old Twangdillo dub'd himſelf a cuckold.

l.hi: The Gods were all call'd in to ſee

lg.l: How fond a huſband Jove could be:

l.hi: He ſtrom'd; ſhe laughed, yet, rouguiſhly
His fury roſe to ſuch a pitch,
He call'd her lewd, caſe-harden'd witch,
Swore, to his girls he'd stick like pitch,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Oh I ſhall burſt!—a pious reſolution!
Means he to put it ſtrait in execution?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Now, now; your pardon's ſign'd; on double wages
You're to light up, and run, your uſual ſtages:
So mount your box, old geeho, I adviſe you
Reſume your taſk diurnal,
He threatens t' advertiſe you
In every weekly Journal.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well, I've a wench, or two—you underſtand me—
And a drole counter plot ſome knaves to catch,
Which in a trice, I will diſpatch,
And then he may command me.

l.hi: Finds her ſpouſe in her arms.
Cuckolds then will know their friends,
And, in like coin may make amends.
And cuckoo that word of fear,
Cuckolds then will know their friends
And cuckoo that word of fear,
And, in like coin may make amends

div.stage: SCENE Midas's Parlour. Midas, Myſis, and Pan, diſcovered in conſultation over a large bowl of punch, pipes and tobacco.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Come, Pan, your toaſt.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here goes, our noble Umpire,

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: And Pol's defeat—I'll pledge it in a bumper.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Hang him, in every ſcheme that whelp has croſs'd us.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Sure he's the devil himſelf

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Or doctor Fauſtus.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Ah! Squire—for Pan wou'd you but ſtoutly ſtickle,
This Pol would ſoon be in a wretched pickle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You reaſon right—

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: His toby I ſhall tickle

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Look, Squire, I've ſold my butter, here it's price is
At your command, do but this jobb for Myſis.
Count 'em.—Six guineas and an old jacobus
Keep Pan, and ſhame that ſcape-grace coram no • us.

l.hi: Mark what I ſay you'll repent if
And not one job for a friend do?
Rouze up, nor thus your grave noddle ſhake,
We'll ſtick to Pan, his party take,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The juſtice in quandary!—Gad, we have him.—
Gammer, Pol's pipe is out; brandy can't ſave him.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Goody, as 'tis your requeſt,
I pocket this here ſtuff,
And, as for that there peaſant,
Truſt me, I'll work his buff.
At the muſical ſtruggle
I'll bully and juggle,
My award's
Your ſure card,
Blood, he ſhall fly his country—that's enough.
sp.stage: AIR VI. To its own Tune.

l.hi: If in the courts your ſuit depend,
Or a cauſe you'd fain do hurt in,
Be ſure you make the judge your friend
By a tip behind the curtain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Well ſaid, my lad of wax—ſince you're ſo mettled
I'll have one tryal with this fop—that's ſettled.
A word i' your ear—You'll find it no hard matter,
When ſhe'as loſt Pol, to nab our crony's daughter.

l.hi: As ſoon as her doating piece fairly is ſped,
Do you make your puſh, and a ſtout one:
For now ſhe has got a ſweetheart in her head,
She'll never be eaſy without one;
Rever'd by the ſhepherds, careſs'd by the nymphs,
No dread or remorſe ſhall come o'er us,
At ſeſſions, in ſpite of the law and its imps,
We'll kick the whole country before us.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ſit down, and make an end o'th' tankard,
I have no head for buſineſs till I've drank hard.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nor have my brains guts in them till they're addle,
When I'm moſt rocky I beſt ſit my ſaddle.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: I always chuck a priming at the tap, or
A cogue of Nantzy, juſt to oil my clapper.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Well come, let's take one bouze, and roar a catch,
Then part to our affairs.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: A catch.

div.stage: AIR VIII. A Catch. Cold and Raw.

l.hi: I'll buffet away from our plain, ſir;
With all my might and main, ſir;
And makes ſuch a woundy racket.
And I warrant we pepper his jackett.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: I'll bluff, &c.

l.hi: He ſhall rue on his knees 'em,
And I with my davy will back it;

sp.speaker: Omn.

l.hi: And I'll warrant we pepper his jacket.

sp.l: Chor. I'll ſwear, I'll ſnare, &c.

div.stage: SCENE Diſcovers Sileno and Damaetas in warm argument, on the lawn before Midas's houſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My Daphne a wife for thee! the ſquire's baſe Pandar!
To the plantations ſooner would I ſend her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Sir, your good wife approv'd my offers.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Name her not, Hag of Endor,
What knew ſhe of thee but by thy coffers?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: And ſhall this ditch-born whelp, this jackanapes.
By dint of congees and ſcrapes—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Theſe are thy ſlanders and that canker'd hag's.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: A thing made up of pilfer'd rags—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Richer than thou with all thy brags
Of flocks, and herds, and money bags.

l.hi: If a rival thy character draw
In perfection he'll find cut flaw,
Make a devil of a ſaint
And change to an Owl a Maccaw.
Can a father pretend to be wiſe
Who his friend's good advice will deſpiſe?
And blinks thro' a green girl's eyes?
Your an impudent pimp and a grub,
You are fool'd by a beggarly ſcrub;
Who will lend me a club,
Your an impudent pimp and a grub,
Your cajol'd by a beggarly ſcrub
Who will rot in a powdering tub,
Whom the prince of impoſtor's I dub;
When you find that your cub
Rub off, ſirrah, rub, ſirrah, rub.
Is debauch'd by a whip'd ſyllabub.

div.stage: Enter Myſis attended by Dapne and Nyſa.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Soh!—you attend the tryal,—we ſhall drive hence
Your vagabond—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I ſmoke your foul contrivance

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Ah Ny, our fate depends upon this iſſue—

sp.speaker: Nyſ Daph.
sp.l: —for your ſake, my claim I here forgo.
And with your Pol, much joy I wiſh you.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: O, gemini, ſay'ſt thou me ſo?
Dear creature let me kiſs you.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Let's kneel, and beg his ſtay, papa will back us.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Mama will ſtorm,

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: What then, ſhe can but whack us.

div.stage: AIR XI. Quintetto. Viens que I'Examine-a-

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: He's ſo charming, &c.

l.hi: Sluts, are you loſt to ſhame?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Muſt Pan reſign, to this fop, his employment?
Muſt, I, to him, yield of Daph. the enjoyment?

l.hi: Ne'er while a tongue I brandiſh,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Midas muſt judge

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: And Pol muſt fly

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Zounds, Pol ſhan't budge,

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Pan's drone is fit for wild rocks and bleak mountains

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Pol's lyre ſuits beſt our cool groves and clear fountains.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Pol is young and merry

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Pan is old and ruſty

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Can you baniſh Pol?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Let Pan fall

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Muſt Pan reſign, to this fop, his employment?

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Pan 's drone is fit for wild rocks and bleak mountains

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Muſt I to Pol, yield of Daph. the enjoyment?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Pol 's lyre ſuits beſt our cool groves and clear fountains.

l.hi: Ne'er while a tongue I brandiſh

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Pol is young and merry

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Pan is old and ruſty.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Daph ſhall blandiſh

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Can you baniſh Pol?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Midas muſt judge,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: And Pol muſt fly

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Pray let Pan fall,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Zounds, Pol ſhan't budge

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Blood, Pan ſhall go

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Poor Pan! poor I!

div.stage: Midas comes forth enrag'd, attended by a crowd of Nymphs and Swains.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Peace ho! is hell broke looſe? what means this jawing?
Under my very noſe this clapper clawing!

l.hi: What the devil's here to do
And each of you tipſey is.
But I'll ſure pull down your pride as

lg.l: A gun, or as I'm juſtice Midas.
Who ſhall oppoſe wiſe juſtice Midas

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: I'm given to underſtand that your all in a pother here
Diſputing whether Pan or Pol, ſhall play to you another year.
Dare you think your clumſey lungs ſo proper to decide as
The delicate ears of juſtice Midas?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: O Tremendous, &c.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Soh! you allow it then—Ye mobbiſh rabble?
Oh, here comes Pol, and Pan—now ſtint your gabble.
Fetch my great chair—I'll quickly end this ſquabble.
sp.stage: AIR XIII. To it's own tune.

l.hi: Like the ſophi on his throne
Shall not call their ſouls their own.
But be tranſported like a thief.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: O Tremendous, &c.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Maſters, will you abide by this condition,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I aſk no better

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: —I am all ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Strik up, ſweet Sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: —Sir, I attend your leiſure

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Pan, take the lead,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: —Since 'tis your worſhip's pleaſure.

l.hi: A pox of your pother about this or that,
Your ſhrieking or ſqueaking ſharp or a flat;
I'm ſharp by my bumpers, you're flat, maſter Pol,
So here goes a ſet-to at Toll de roll loll.
When Beauty her pack of poor lovers would hamper,
And after miſs Will o' the Wiſp the fools ſcamper,
Ding dong, in ſing ſong, they the lady extol;

lg.l: Pray what's all this fuſs for, but—Toll de roll, &c.

l.hi: Mankind are a medley—a chance-medley race,
All ſtart in full cry to give dame Fortune chace;
There's catch as catch can, hit or miſs Luck is all,
And Luck's the beſt tune of life's Toll lol de roll.
I've done, pleaſe your worſhip, 'tis rather too long,
I only meant life is but an old ſong;
The world's but a tragedy, comedy, droll,
Where all act the ſcene of Toll loll de rol lol.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: By jingo, well perform'd for one of his age;
How, hang dog, don't you bluſh to ſhew your viſage?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why, maſter Midas, for that matter,
'Tis enough to daſh one,
To hear the arbitrator,
In ſuch unſeemly faſhion
One of the candidates beſpatter
With ſo much partial paſſion.

l.hi: But, from her charms when ſunder'd,
Each hour will ſeem an hundred,

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Silence—this juſt decree all, at your peril
Obedient hear,—elſe I ſhall uſe you very ill.
Oh tremendous, &c.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: All bow with me to mighty Pan—enthrone him.—
No pouting—and with feſtal chorus crown him!—
sp.stage: [The crowd forms two ranks beſide the chair, and join in the chorus, whilſt Midas crowns him with bays.]

lg.l: Crown'd with bays, his due reward.
While, with ecchoing ſhouts of praiſe

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: 'Tis well!—what keeps you here—you ragamuffin?
Go trudge—or do you wait for a good cuffing?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now, liſten all—The wrath of Jove, for rapine,
Corruption, luſt, pride, fraud, there's no eſcaping.
Tremble, thou wretch—Thou'ſt ſtretch'd thy utmoſt tether,
Thou, and thy tools ſhall go to pot together.

l.hi: God of muſic and king of Parnaſs:
I reward with the ears of an aſs.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Detected, baulk'd, and ſmall,
On our marrow bones we fall.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Detected, baulk'd, and ſmall,
On our marrow bones we fall.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Detected, baulk'd, and ſmall,
On our marrow bones we fall.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.l: Be merciful,
Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Be pitiful,
Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Forgive us, mighty Sol,
Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Pol.

l.hi: With, strumpets and bailiffs ſhall claſs.

sp.l: He a ſtinking old goat, thou an aſs, an aſs, &c.

sp.speaker: Mid., Mys., Dam.
sp.l: Alas! Alas!

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Now my heart's cur'd of folly.

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: —Be jolly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The Oracle's word
For millions ſhould paſs.
Myſis is well parted,

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: And the pimp carted,

sp.speaker: Nyſ.
sp.l: Squire. Midas converted
Into an aſs, O the dull aſs!

sp.speaker: Daph., Sil., Myſ., Dam., Apollo.
sp.stage: All together, but to ſeveral airs, while Midas joins in chorus, braying like an aſs.
sp.l: Into an aſs, laugh at the aſs!
Into an aſs, a real aſs!
What a ſad aſs,
Alas, alas!
Be thou an aſs.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: Be thou ſquire—his eſtate to Sil.
To thee I tranſlate.
To you his ſtrong cheſts, wicked maſs, to Daph. & Nyſa.
Live happy, while I,
Recall'd to the ſky,
Make all the Gods laugh at Midas.

sp.speaker: Apol., Dam., Mid., Mys., Daph., Nyſ., Sil.
sp.l: All the Gods laugh at Midas.
Alas, Alas! Exit.
[Goes about braying like an aſs]
What a ſad paſs—Ah, poor Midas.
Chang'd to an aſs—Well bray'd Midas.
Well bray'd Midas; manifeſt aſs.
Laugh at the aſs; laugh at the aſs.

sp.speaker: Daph., Sil., Nyſ.
sp.stage: Together, with the other nymphs and ſwains.
sp.l: To the bright God of day
Let us dance, ſing, and play,
Clap hands every lad with his 'laſs.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Now criticks lye ſnug,
Not a hiſs, groan, or ſhrug,
Remember the fate of Midas, Midas,
Remember the fate of Midas.
Now criticks lye ſnug, &c.
